topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jess Lachs, her DoorDash history, and frames the episode focus: building/scaling a high-impact data org in a complex marketplace business.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Webflow and Anvil.

topics.title: Analytics as a business-driving seat at table
topics.summary: Jess explains her philosophy that analytics should drive business impact (answering “so what / what now”), not operate as a ticket-taking dashboard service.

topics.title: Centralized vs embedded data org model
topics.summary: Jess defines central vs embedded reporting lines, argues for a centralized center-of-excellence model, and describes how DoorDash uses pods aligned to partner orgs while keeping central reporting.

topics.title: Benefits of centralization: talent, growth, consistency
topics.summary: Jess outlines key advantages: consistent hiring bar, better career mobility/retention, shared methodologies/metrics, less duplicated work, and stronger team culture/brand.

topics.title: Balancing reactive requests with proactive deep dives
topics.summary: They discuss how to protect time for exploratory work despite constant inbound asks, including intentional goal-setting and running analytics hackathons.

topics.title: Hackathon case study: referral fraud discovery
topics.summary: Jess shares a hackathon deep dive into referrals that uncovered a bimodal distribution driven by fraud; the work led to recommendations like fraud checks and referral caps.

topics.title: How data teams push back: trade-offs and prioritization
topics.summary: Jess explains a practical approach to saying no: align on shared goals, make trade-offs explicit, and regularly re-prioritize with partners—while occasionally doing quick asks to build goodwill.

topics.title: Hiring for curiosity and real-world problem solving
topics.summary: Jess describes what she looks for beyond technical skills—especially curiosity—and how DoorDash interviews use coding plus real DoorDash case problems to test ambiguity handling and adaptability.

topics.title: Non-traditional path into data leadership
topics.summary: Jess recounts becoming a data scientist out of necessity at DoorDash, self-teaching SQL/Python, and leveraging a pragmatic business-impact lens while hiring deep technical experts.

topics.title: Habits behind success: first principles and competitiveness
topics.summary: Jess attributes her growth to solving the problem in front of her, unblocking herself, and a competitive “do what it takes” mindset rooted in DoorDash’s early culture.

topics.title: Early DoorDash stories and customer-first culture
topics.summary: Jess shares stories from launching Boston (handing out promo codes at 5am) and a major outage where everyone did support; emphasizes extreme ownership and doing right by customers.

topics.title: WeDash program and building empathy across marketplace
topics.summary: Jess explains DoorDash’s WeDash program where employees dash or do support quarterly to build empathy, uncover product issues, and stay close to merchants/dashers/consumers.

topics.title: Instilling extreme ownership in data teams
topics.summary: They discuss how extreme ownership is cultural and expected: data scientists go beyond role boundaries (e.g., calling customers) to unblock decisions; this also enables cross-functional career moves.

topics.title: Defining great metrics: inputs, simplicity, common currency
topics.summary: Jess shares lessons from bad metrics: avoid goaling on lagging outcomes like retention, prefer actionable input metrics, keep metrics simple (avoid opaque composites), and translate levers into a shared currency like GOV/volume for trade-offs.
